channel.name: x.toBigInt() was called on a variable field element `x` in provable code.

messages.content: I am running some code in a `Provable.witness()` but when I compile a ZKapp, I get the error in the title.  Is it possible to use a witness in provable code?
Can you share the original code? 🤔
Sorry I was trying to create a good example, but I can't repro it yet, will keep working and get back to you

@Florian at least one of the instances of my problem here was initializing `let f = Field(0)` and then calling `f.add(x[0])`.  Different times during compilation/proving when the code ran, `x` could be a constant of a var, but `Field(0)` is always constant.

Fixed by doing, instead:

```
const initValue = x[0];
let f = initValue;
...
f.add(x[1])
```

So whether x is a variable Field or a constant, it can be added.

Though find this concept very confusing.  If it's possible, I feel that `Field(0)` should be able to be used in either case.  `0 + x[0]` is always the same as `x[0]` and allows for a more natural loop over my array of Fields.

@45930 I still don't understand the problem you had here. In the title you said it threw on x.toBigInt(), which I guess makes sense and is pretty well explained in the error message.
But now you're saying you couldn't do Field.add(). But add() shouldn't produce that error you posted. Or does it?
If add produces the x.toBigInt() problem, then that's a bug we have to fix
That line in `Field` was throwing for me, and it was resolved by replacing `lef f;` with thee first element of my fields array instead of the constant zero.
So in other words `Field(0).add(x)` was throwing for you, where `x` is a variable?? that definitely shouldn't happen
I will see if I can repro it later
I had a lot of moving pieces getting this code to work in a proof

By the way, do you guys have a good way to test features in a smart contract?  I found it hard to be confident that when I add or change a feature that it would continue to work.  Does it make sense to actually write a smart contract implementation in my package to run tests on?
When I want to check that my stuff works in a proof I'd usually whip up a ZkProgram and do the compile/prove/verify cycle
SmartContract is more involved bc you have to set up accounts, deploy, create a tx etc
